article.title: Main Window
article.para: The window's title shows the name of the currently loaded file in square brackets, with an asterisk on it's right side if the file has been changed. If a file is loaded the main area has data laid out like this:

On the left are the offsets of the first byte in the line in hexadecimal notation. You can choose the offset length or make it automatically adjusted to the length of the largest offset from the View Settings -dialog ( Options
View Settings) or right-click the offsets to increment their lengths or left-click them to decrement their lengths (when auto-adjust is off). In middle are the actual byte values, with vertical separating lines after every fourth byte in the line. You can choose the number of bytes to display per line from View Settings-dialog and also, if it should be automatically adjusted to the window width. In the riight are the character representations of these values. Values that do not have a printable character presentation are shown with a dot. You can choose the character set for these representations as well as the font size with the Character Set -dialog ( Options
Character set) . As you can see, the first byte of the second line of the sample hexdump has the hexadecimal value 64 and the corresponding character is a lower case "d". The position after the last byte of the file is marked with a double underscore "__" in the byte section.

Blinking in the window somewhere is a rectangular caret, if the window is enabled. If the caret is in the byte section, then it stands on either of the two nibbles (half-bytes). If the caret is in the character section, then it stands on one character corresponding with one byte. In either case the corresponding other representation is shown inverted in the other section.

On the bottom of the window is the status bar, which displays additional information. In the first section of the status bar you can find the current offset of the byte which the caret is marking in hexadecimal and decimal notation. Next are the bits of the current byte. Also in this section, on the right side, is something like this:
These are the values of the byte (B:), the word (W:) and the double word (longword) (L:) value starting at this offset in decimal notation. These numbers are computed depending on the two settings:

Binary mode ).
Signed or unsigned values. Can be selected in View Settings-dialog.

article.para: The second section of the status bar has indicators for:

listitem.simpara: entering mode: OVR for overwriting or INS for inserting on keyboard input. If Frhed is in read-only mode, then there will be a READ here.
binary mode: L for Little-endian or B for Big-endian.

article.para: The third section is the file size in bytes.
The status bar can also be used to toggle various parameters and act as a shortcut to certain commands.

The status bar takes into account the same factors when considering if the selected command should be carried out as the menus do when disabling commands. If there are 2 alternatives in one place and one is disabled then the other one will be used.

A single left click in the third section is a shortcut to Edit
Append (right is Edit
File properties ) - Note that this may change in the future.
Clicking in the middle section will toggle the parameter clicked on - ANSI ↔ OEM, READ → INS → OVR → READ… (right-click goes back other way) , L ↔ B.
Left or right clicking in the first section can result in many different things depending on where you click and the state of the file opened.

When part of the file is selected you may deselect (cursor goes to the first nibble of the first byte of the selection or last of last for a right click) by clicking in the space on the right or the word Selected: or alter the selection using Edit
Select block by clicking in the offsets region.

If the file is empty clicking the first part will bring up Edit
Append .

If the file is not empty and the cursor is on the end byte then
Edit
Goto will be activated on a left click or the cursor goes to the previous byte on a right click.

article.para: The window also has a vertical and a horizontal scrollbar, which can be used to scroll the view. They don't change the caret position.
